actions-list.header: On motion to recommit Roll Call 407
actions-list.actionItem: Yea and Nay vote pending.
The previous question on the motion to recommit was ordered pursuant to clause 2(b) of rule XIX.
Mr. Magaziner moved to recommit to the Committee on Homeland Security.
The House adopted the amendments en gros as agreed to by the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House rose from the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union to report H.R. 1516.
On agreeing to the Cline amendment; Agreed to by recorded vote: (Roll no. 406).
The House resolved into Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union for further consideration.

Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 1516 — "To establish Department of Homeland Security funding restrictions on institutions of higher education that have a relationship with Confucius Institutes, and for other purposes."
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of September 10.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is subject to the call of the Chair.
Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union rises leaving H.R. 1516 as unfinished business.
On motion that the committee rise Agreed to by voice vote.
Mr. Guest moved that the committee rise.
On agreeing to the Nunn (IA) amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1430, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Nunn (IA) amendment No. 6.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Nunn (IA),  numbered 6 printed in Part C of House Report 118-656 to add the Thousand Talents Program to the list of restricted, "Chinese Entities of Concern."
On agreeing to the Cline amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1430, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Cline amendment No. 5.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Cline,  numbered 5 printed in Part C of House Report 118-656 to add the Chinese Academy of Sciences to the bill's definition of a "Chinese entity of concern."

At the conclusion of debate on the Cline amendment No. 4, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Thompson (MS) demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1430, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Cline amendment No. 4.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Cline,  numbered 4 printed in Part C of House Report 118-656 to require the Secretary of Homeland Security to report to Congress any institution of higher education that has a relationship with a Confucius Institute or Chinese entity of concern and receives funds from the Department of Homeland Security.
On agreeing to the Crockett amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1430, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Crockett amendment No. 3.

An amendment, offered by Ms. Crockett,  numbered 3 printed in Part C of House Report 118-656 to add engaging in efforts to interfere in U.S. federal, state, and local elections to List of Qualifications for "Entities of Concern."
On agreeing to the Stauber amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1430, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Stauber amendment No. 2.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Stauber,  numbered 2 printed in Part C of House Report 118-656 to amend the definition of "Chinese entities of concern" in section 2 to include "aides, abets, or enables the detention, imprisonment, persecution, or forced labor of Uyghur Muslims."
On agreeing to the Gottheimer amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1430, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Gottheimer amendment No. 1.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Gottheimer,  numbered 1 printed in Part C of House Report 118-656 to add the Delegitimization of U.S.-Taiwan Relations to List of Qualifications for "Entities of Concern."
The Committee of the Whole proceeded with one hour of general debate on H.R. 1516.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Stephanie I. Bice to act as Chairwoman of the Committee.
House resolved itself into the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union pursuant to H. Res. 1430 and Rule XVIII.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 1398, H.R. 1425, H.R. 1516, H.R. 7980, H.R. 9456 and H.R. 9494. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 1398, H.R. 1425, and H.R. 1516 under a structured rule and H.R. 7980, H.R. 9456, and H.R. 9494 under a closed rule. The resolution provides for one hour of general debate and one motion to recommit on each bill.

Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 1430. H.R. 1516 — "To establish Department of Homeland Security funding restrictions on institutions of higher education that have a relationship with Confucius Institutes, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to without objection.
Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 1431 — "Electing Members to certain standing committees of the House of Representatives."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 413
actions-list.actionItem: 3 (Roll no. 405).

Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 1103 — "To require the President to remove the extension of certain privileges, exemptions, and immunities to the Hong Kong Economic and Trade Offices if Hong Kong no longer enjoys a high degree of autonomy from the People's Republic of China, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by recorded vote: 209
On ordering the previous question Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 193

actions-list.actionItem: Considered as unfinished business. H. Res. 1430 — "Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 1398) to establish the CCP Initiative program, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 1425) to require any convention, agreement, or other international instrument on pandemic prevention, preparedness, and response reached by the World Health Assembly to be subject to Senate ratification; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 1516) to establish Department of Homeland Security funding restrictions on institutions of higher education that have a relationship with Confucius Institutes, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 7980) to amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to exclude vehicles the batteries of which contain materials sourced from prohibited foreign entities from the clean vehicle credit; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 9456) to amend the Defense Production Act of 1950 with respect to foreign investments in United States agriculture, and for other purposes; and providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 9494) making continuing appropriations for fiscal year 2025, and for other purposes."
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of September 10.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess for a period of less than 15 minutes.

At the conclusion of debate on H. Res. 1430, the Chair put the question on ordering the previous question and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. McGovern demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 1430.

Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 1430 — "Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 1398) to establish the CCP Initiative program, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 1425) to require any convention, agreement, or other international instrument on pandemic prevention, preparedness, and response reached by the World Health Assembly to be subject to Senate ratification; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 1516) to establish Department of Homeland Security funding restrictions on institutions of higher education that have a relationship with Confucius Institutes, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 7980) to amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to exclude vehicles the batteries of which contain materials sourced from prohibited foreign entities from the clean vehicle credit; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 9456) to amend the Defense Production Act of 1950 with respect to foreign investments in United States agriculture, and for other purposes; and providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 9494) making continuing appropriations for fiscal year 2025, and for other purposes."
The House proceeded with one minute speeches which by direction of the Chair, would be limited to 15 per side of the aisle.
The Chair designated Mr. Langworthy to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal.  Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by Rev. Lisa Wink Schultz, Office of the Senate Chaplain, Washington DC
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of September 10.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 12:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 12:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Greg Pence to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
